newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Nov 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Nov 20.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Reserve Bank deputy governor Timothy Thahane has announced a major overhaul of the Bank's administration of exchange controls to remove red tape and facilitate deals.

- A countrywide truckers' strike was set to go ahead despite an 11th-hour agreement between seven transport unions and road freight employers to appoint top mediators to intervene in the wage dispute.

- KwaZulu-Natal's budget over-expenditure for the current financial year was estimated at 1.1 billion rand, with the main culprits being the education and welfare departments, the provincial treasury secretary said.
- Farmers and timber and paper companies such as Sappi Ltd and Mondi have teamed up to hire private security to combat rising crime in rural KwaZulu-Natal.
- Virgin VA.Cn boss Richard Branson is talking to the South African government about setting up a "people's lottery" with 100 percent of profit going to upliftment projects and charitable causes.
- The Reserve Bank has urged the government to implement its macro-economic policy more quickly, saying this could accelerate the pace of exchange control liberalisation.

- The rand's fall of almost 30 percent against the dollar since February will result in the Reserve Bank's realising a net loss of about five billion rand on its forward cover book in the 12 months to March 31, according to economist Vic de Klerk of stockbrokers PLJ van Rensburg.

- Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, a subsidiary of Europe's largest banking group, has demonstrated its full commitment to South Africa by buying the remaining 50 percent of the shares in stockbroking firm Ivor Jones Roy & Co that it did not own.
- Truck drivers were determined to embark on a national strike despite urgent conciliation talks which were under way to solve their wage dispute.

- The National Empowerment Consortium's chief negotiator Cyril Ramaphosa has formally been appointed chairman of Johnnies Industrial Corp (Johnnic), after the consortium bought a 35 percent stake in Johnnic for 2.6 billion rand last month.
- The Supreme Court is to sentence a woman convicted of stealing a new-born baby and keeping the child for nearly two years.
